Building Network Clients

Zilogic Systems

Network Sockets

Introduction

  • An interface between the application and the transport layer.
  • It is also an endpoint in a communication link between two processes.

Clients and Servers

  • Server is a process that provides services to other processes.
  • Example: Apaache web server, bind DNS server, postfix mail server
  • Client is a process that requests the service of server.
  • Example: Firefox web browser, Thunderbird mail client
  • Protocol is a common agreement between clients and servers, on how data is to be transmitted, and interpreted.
  • Example: The mail protocol (POP) says that a client should authenticate itself using the USER <username> and PASS <password> commands. The list of emails can be obtained using the LIST command. The email can be retrieved using the the RETR command followed by the email no. This set of commands and the order in which it should be invoked constitutes the mail protocol.

TCP and UDP

Reliability

TCP guarantees that the message sent will reach the receiver, unless there is a serious problem in the communication path, in which case the sender will be notified of the issue.

UDP does not ensure that the message sent will reach the receiver. It also does not notify the sender when the message sent is not delivered. A single message could also be received by the receiver twice!

Connection

TCP is connection oriented. A connection has to be established before data transaction can take place, similar to the telephone/mobile system. This is a direct consequence of the protocol being reliable.

UDP is not connection oriented. No connection has to be established before sending data.

Ordering

TCP ensures that messages sent by the sender, are received in the same order by the receiver.

With UDP messages sent can be received out of order.

Data Interface to Application

With TCP, the receiver has no indication two messages were sent with separate transmit syscalls. The tranmission is said to be stream oriented. The data sent and received is perceived as a sequence of bytes.

In UDP, each message sent is to be received by the receiver by separate receive syscalls. The tranmission is said to be message oriented. The data is sent and received as messages.

Applications

UDP’s misfeatures make it suitable for realtime multimedia streaming. Since it is light weight it used in embedded system protocols like TFTP and SNMP.

Creating Sockets

  • To create a socket, the socket() system call can be used. 
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

fd = socket(proto_family, type, protocol);

int proto_family;
int type;
int protocol;
int fd;
  • The proto_family specifies the protocol stack to be used for communication - IP, IPX, AppleTalk, … It is specified using macros PF_INET, PF_IPX, PF_APPLETALK.
  • The type specifies the transport mechanism to be used. It is one of SOCK_STREAM or SOCK_DGRAM for IP. SOCK_STREAM says that a reliable, connection based, byte stream transmission is required. SOCK_DGRAM says that a unreliable, connection-less, message based transmission is required.
  • If there are more than one transport protocols that can provide a particular transmission type, then protocol specifies protocol number of the transport protocol. If protocol == 0 then the default protocol for the specified transmission type is used.
  • In case of TCP/IP, there is only one protocol that provides SOCK_STREAM — TCP. It is the default.
  • There is also only one protocol that provides SOCK_DGRAM —  UDP. It is the default.
  • The syscall returns a file descriptor on success, or -1 on failure. errno is set to indicate what error occurred.
  • Once a socket is created an interface is available to the transport layer.
  • In the case of SOCK_STREAM the socket cannot be used till it is connected to a server.
Figure 1. Socket Created

TCP Socket Operations

Connecting to a Server

  • Connecting is a must for TCP sockets.
  • It is more like a mobile phone. To talk to another person, first the phone connects to the other phone.
    • The user has to enter the other mobile no. and press call.
    • The phone tries to connect to the other mobile.
    • Various exceptional conditions can occur
      1. The mobile no. is incorrect.
      2. The mobile is not reachable.
      3. The mobile is busy, i.e. connected to another mobile.
      4. The mobile is free, but the user does not pick the phone.
    • Or the user accepts the call, and the connection is made.
    • Both the users can talk till either end terminates the connection.
  • To connect to a server the connect() syscall can be used. 
#include <sys/socket.h>

ret = connect(fd, (struct sockaddr *)&addr, sizeof(addr));

int fd;
struct sockaddr_in addr;
  • fd is the local socket to be connected.
  • addr is an inet socket address structure, that specifies the server IP and port to connect to.
  • The socket address structure pointer should be casted to a pointer to the generic socket address type.
Figure 2. Socket Connected
  • On failure connect() returns -1 and sets errno accordingly.
  • connect() can fail for a no. of reasons, just as a mobile phone.
  • If the IP address of the server is incorrect. The error code is set to ENETUNREACH, meaning "Network is unreachable".
  • If the server is busy and does not respond within a timeout period, the error code is set to ETIMEDOUT.
  • For a complete list of possible errors, see the connect() man page.

Sending and Receiving Data

  • Since the socket is represented by a file descriptor. It can be treated just like a file after the connection has been established.
  • To receive data the read() syscall can be used. 
ret = read(fd, buf, len);

int fd;
void *buf;
size_t len;
ssize_t ret;
  • If ret > 0, data received from peer.
  • If ret == 0, connection has been closed by peer.
  • If ret == -1, network error has occured.
  • To send data the write() syscall can be used. 
ret = write(fd, buf, len);

int fd;
char *buf;
size_t len;
ssize_t ret;
  • If ret > 0, data sent to peer.
  • If ret == -1, network error has occured.
  • The invoking process receives SIGPIPE, if the connection has been closed by peer.

Terminating the Connection

  • When the client or the server wants to terminate the connection, the close() syscall can be used.
  • This is analogous to pressing the On Hook button in the mobile phone.
  • What happens when one end closes the connection is indicated in the previous section.

Daytime

Introduction

  • ASCII protocol
  • The client connects to the server, the servers provides the day and time as an ascii string and closes the connection.
  • The protocol is defined in the document RFC867.

Day Time

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

#include <netdb.h>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <error.h>
#include <errno.h>

#define DAYTIME_PORT 13
/* IP Address: 172.16.0.2 */
#define SHARK_IP  0xAC100002

int main()
{
        int sock_fd;
        int ret;
        FILE *sock_fp;
        char buf[256];

        struct sockaddr_in saddr = {
                AF_INET,
                htons(DAYTIME_PORT),
                htonl(SHARK_IP)
        };

        /* 1. Create a TCP socket. */
        sock_fd = socket(PF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);
        if (sock_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error opening socket");

        /* 2. Establish a TCP connection to the server. */
        ret = connect(sock_fd, (struct sockaddr *) &saddr,
                      sizeof(saddr));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error connecting to server");

        /* 3. Read the date and time sent by the server. */
        while (1) {
                int i;

                ret = read(sock_fd, buf, sizeof(buf));
                if (ret == -1)
                        error(1, errno, "error reading socket");
                else if (ret == 0)
                        break;
                else
                        for (i = 0; i < ret; i++)
                                putchar(buf[i]);
        }

        /* 4. Close the connection. */
        close(sock_fd);

        return 0;
}

Day Time

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

#include <netdb.h>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <error.h>
#include <errno.h>

#define DAYTIME_PORT 13

int main()
{
        char *server = "time-a.nist.gov";
        // char *server = "shark";
        int sock_fd;
        struct hostent *hostent;
        struct sockaddr_in server_addr;
        int ret;
        FILE *sock_fp;
        char *retp;
        int i;
        char buf[256];

        /* 1. Create a TCP socket. */
        sock_fd = socket(PF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);
        if (sock_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error opening socket");

        /* 2. Convert the host name to an IP address. */
        hostent = gethostbyname(server);
        if (hostent == NULL)
                error(1, 0, "error resolving hostname %s: %s", server,
                      hstrerror(h_errno));

        /* 3. Create a socket address structure with the server address and port no. */
        server_addr.sin_family = AF_INET;
        server_addr.sin_port = htons(DAYTIME_PORT);
        server_addr.sin_addr = *((struct in_addr *)hostent->h_addr_list[0]);

        /* 4. Establish a TCP connection to the server. */
        ret = connect(sock_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&server_addr, sizeof(server_addr));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error connecting to %s", server);

        /* 5. Read the date and time sent by the server. */
        while (1) {
                ret = read(sock_fd, buf, sizeof(buf));
                if (ret == -1)
                        error(1, errno, "error reading socket");
                else if (ret == 0)
                        break;
                else
                        for (i = 0; i < ret; i++)
                                putchar(buf[i]);
        }

        /* 6. Close the connection. */
        ret = close(sock_fd);
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error shutting socket");

        return 0;
}

HTTP

Introduction

  • ASCII protocol
  • For each transaction a separate connection.
    • client connects to server
    • client sends request
    • server responds with web page
    • connection is closed
  • Simplest HTTP request 
GET <path-to-file>
  • Server responds with the file contents.
  • Program to download a file through HTTP.

Download program with error handling

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <fcntl.h>
#include <unistd.h>

#include <netdb.h>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <error.h>
#include <errno.h>
#include <string.h>

int writeb(int fd, char *bufp, size_t nbytes)
{
        int written;

        while (nbytes != 0) {
                written = write(fd, bufp, nbytes);
                if (written == -1)
                        return -1;

                if (written <= nbytes) {
                        bufp += written;
                        nbytes -= written;
                }
        }

        return 0;
}

void send_get_request(int sock_fd, char *rpath)
{
        char req[] = "GET ";
        char eol[] = "\r\n";
        int ret;

        ret = writeb(sock_fd, req, strlen(req));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error writing to socket");

        ret = writeb(sock_fd, rpath, strlen(rpath));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error writing to socket");

        ret = writeb(sock_fd, eol, strlen(eol));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error writing to socket");

        ret = writeb(sock_fd, eol, strlen(eol));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error writing to socket");
}

void recv_file(int sock_fd, char *lpath)
{
        int file_fd;
        char buf[1024];
        int rlen;

        file_fd = open(lpath, O_WRONLY | O_TRUNC | O_CREAT, 0660);
        if (file_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error opening file %s for writing", lpath);

        while (1) {
                rlen = read(sock_fd, buf, sizeof(buf));
                if (rlen == -1)
                        error(1, errno, "error reading from socket");

                if (rlen == 0)
                        break;

                writeb(file_fd, buf, rlen);
        }

        close(file_fd);
}

int make_connection(char *server)
{
        int sock_fd;
        struct hostent *hostent;
        struct sockaddr_in server_addr;
        int ret;

        sock_fd = socket(PF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);
        if (sock_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error opening socket");

        hostent = gethostbyname(server);
        if (hostent == NULL)
                error(1, 0, "error resolving hostname %s: %s", server,
                      hstrerror(h_errno));

        server_addr.sin_family = AF_INET;
        server_addr.sin_port = htons(80);
        server_addr.sin_addr = *((struct in_addr *)hostent->h_addr_list[0]);

        ret = connect(sock_fd, (struct sockaddr *)&server_addr, sizeof(server_addr));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error connecting to %s", server);

        return sock_fd;
}

int main()
{
        char *server = "www.zilogic.com";
        char *rpath = "/static/images/logo/logo.png";
        char *lpath = "logo.png";

        int sock_fd;

        sock_fd = make_connection(server);
        send_get_request(sock_fd, rpath);
        recv_file(sock_fd, lpath);

        return 0;
}

UDP Socket Operations

Introduction

  • UDP sockets do not require a connection.
  • They are similar to letters. To send a some message to another person.
    • The message is written in a letter.
    • The destination address is specified.
    • The letter is posted.
  • Each time a message is to be sent, the above process is repeated. Even if the message is to be sent to the same person.

Sending and Receiving Datagrams

  • To send a datagram the sendto() syscall is to be used. 
ret = sendto(fd, buf, buflen, flags,
             (struct sockaddr *)to_addrp,
             sizeof(*to_addrp))

int fd;
void *buf;
size_t buflen;
int flags;
struct sockaddr_in *to_addrp;
  • fd is the socket to be used to send data.
  • buf is the buffer to be sent.
  • buflen is the size of the buffer.
  • flags tell the underlying protocol to behave in a certain way. We will not discuss this further. If no flags are required, 0 can be passed.
  • to_addrp is a pointer to the destination socket address, cast to a pointer of the generic addresss type.
  • The function returns the no. of characters sent. On error it returns -1 and sets errno appropriately.
  • To receive a datagram the recvfrom() syscall is to be used. 
ret = recvfrom(fd, buf, buflen, flags,
               (struct sockddr *)&from_addr,
               &from_len));
int fd;
void *buf;
size_t buflen;
int flags;
struct sockaddr_in from_addr;
socklen_t from_len;
  • The arguments are same as sendto().
  • If the fifth argument is not NULL, the address of the sender is stored.
  • from_len specifies the size of the address structure passed. The syscall modifies from_len to the actual sizeof the structure returned. In case of IP, both the passed structure and returned structure size are the same.
  • There are some protocols in which the size of the address structure, varies with the address. The from_len argument is useful in those protocols.

Dashboard Protocol

Introduction

  • The Dashboard protocol is used to control the dashboard of a vehicle.
  • The protocol uses UDP.
  • The Dashboard message have the following format: 
<dial><value>
  • dial - S for Speed and F for Fuel
  • value - value for the specified dial.

Program to set the fuel dial

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <arpa/inet.h>
#include <unistd.h>

#include <netdb.h>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <error.h>
#include <errno.h>

int main(int argc, char *argv[])
{
        int sock_fd;
        char buf[1024];
        struct sockaddr_in addr;
        int ret;
        char *level;

        if (argc != 2) {
                puts("Usage: fuel <level>\n");
                exit(1);
        }

        level = argv[1];

        /* 1. Create a UDP socket. */
        sock_fd = socket(PF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM, 0);
        if (sock_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error opening socket");

        /* 2. Create the datagram contents. */
        snprintf(buf, sizeof(buf), "F%d", atoi(level));

        /* 4. Create the destination address */
        addr.sin_family = AF_INET;
        addr.sin_port = htons(5000);

        /* 4a. Convert the IP string into a network ordered IP address. */
        ret = inet_pton(AF_INET, "127.0.0.1", &addr.sin_addr);
        if (ret == 0)
                error(1, 0, "invalid address");
        if (ret < 0)
                error(1, errno, "invalid address");

        /* 5. Send the datagram. */
        ret = sendto(sock_fd, buf, strlen(buf), 0,
                     (struct sockaddr *)&addr, sizeof(addr));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error sending datagram");

        /* 6. Close the socket. */
        close(sock_fd);

        return 0;
}
